The Origin of Matter

The science of Chemistry, like Physics (History Tracers Team, Physics), goes beyond the limits of planet Earth. When studying the birth of galaxies, for example, we can identify chemical elements that are essential for life (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 10).

Like any science, Chemistry is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps, which is dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that part before continuing (History Tracers Team, First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or Chemistry before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-Chemistry or pre-Chemistry, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge).

In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Chemistry and proto-Chemistry, gradually connecting them to Chemistry through mathematics.
Chapter 1: The Origin of What We Observe

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: In this text, we take a journey back in time to understand what current measurements reveal about the universe’s past.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good vs. evil, left vs. right, matter vs. energy, up vs. down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up doing omissions

value.name: Always present
value.desc: many times we are so focused on ourselves or on opposites that we do not notice what is always present.

value.name: Evolution of Knowledge: The Atom
value.desc: In this text, we study how our idea of the atom has evolved over time.

value.name: The four divisions
value.desc: in addition to the four limbs of the human body, the number four has also been used in various contexts throughout the history of humanity.

value.name: Dividing again
value.desc: When we perform a division, we can repeat it — but how can we represent this idea in the language of mathematics?
